title: Top 5 Agent Interaction Patterns for Scaling Engineering Impact
summary: A strategic guide to maximizing AI agent potential by understanding five core interaction patterns. The workflow progresses from simple Human-in-the-Loop interactions to complex Full Application architectures, offering a decision framework to balance complexity with scalability.

steps.action: Execute Iterative HIL (Human in the Loop)
steps.tool: Gemini CLI / Claude Code, Replicate MCP
steps.reasoning: Establishes baseline accuracy and control through direct human oversight; ideal for debugging and initial problem exploration but lacks scalability.
The 80/20 pattern for efficiency; standardizes workflows by codifying repetitive tasks into version-controlled commands, removing manual friction.
Enables parallel execution and domain specialization (e.g., separate creation and editing agents) for complex, multi-faceted tasks.
Centralizes routing logic and tool access, creating a single, encapsulated integration point that allows multiple agents to interact with unique assets or services.
Provides maximum control, extensibility, and customizability for long-term product visions where off-the-shelf agent interactions are insufficient.
Ensures complexity is earned; dictates starting with ad-hoc prompts and only scaling to higher patterns when specific friction points (repetition, need for parallelization) arise.

key_takeaways: Complexity should be earned, not assumed; start with ad-hoc prompts and scale only when friction arises.
Reusable Prompts (Pattern 2) represent the 80/20 high-leverage point for most engineering workflows.
Use Sub-Agents specifically when tasks require parallelization and distinct domain expertise.
MCP Wrappers are essential for encapsulating logic and exposing unique assets to multiple agent types.
